results.title: Get out and live
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Echoes in Freestone
results.creator_credit: Ray Barnes, John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Using sounds from the past, over pictures of the present, the film glimpses a man’s life in pioneering days. Set in the historic town of Richmond, Tasmania, the film shows some of the classic colonial Georgian houses and churches, many of which date from the early days.

results.title: Easy does it
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1967 film is a light-hearted look at the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back strain and injury. The film shows footage of factory and manual labourers handling various heavy loads, including using equipment to aid safe lifting. This footage is interspersed with examples of everyday strain such as women hanging out the washing and lifting a baby from a pram; and moments of slapstick comedy as a man struggles to carry his bride over the threshold of their house and a man lifts a keg of beer at a barbeque.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Blowfly menace
results.creator_credit: A. C. McKay BVSc and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: For farmers and graziers this study of the life-cycle of the green blowfly and other flies associated with blowfly strike in sheep, and demonstrations of various methods of control, should prove both useful and interesting.

results.title: To my dearest beloved one - Shewitey Mearey
results.brief_description: A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Journeys with Breast Cancer” Created in association with Breast Cancer Network Australia. “I said to the doctor, I don’t care if I die tomorrow but I don’t want to leave my daughter alone. He said to me that first I had to live before I could have another child.”

results.title: 'A'
results.creator_credit: Argos Films Borresholm, Jan Lenica and Renate Duhr
results.brief_description: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Argos Films Borresholm, Jan Lenica and Renate Duhr
results.description: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)
description_for_label: Streaming site Hulu’s long awaiting movie Death on the Nile has gone viral as viewers question the quality of the CGI. Based on an Agatha Christie novel, the murder mystery is set in 1930s Egypt but was predominately shot in the UK. Clips of the worst offending scene have been shared online and retweeted almost 9,000 times, with viewers likening the special effects to low budget productions of the 1990s. Some defended its use, explaining that it was made at the height of the pandemic when people couldn’t travel, while others wondered if it was a ‘stylistic nod’ to the sound stages of Old Hollywood.

results.title: head_phone_film_poems
results.brief_description:
head_phone_film_poems is a collection of thirteen films that creatively remix material from online archives including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) film material in the National Archives of Australia, crime scene photographs from the Justice and Police Museum Sydney, and Gibson’s own social-media-stored collection of strange late-night phenomena filmed in his neighbourhood over the past decade. Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

[Sourced from ACMI website event page https://www.acmi.net.au/whats-on/ross-gibson-head_phone_film_poems/ 9/6/2021]
results.description: head_phone_film_poems is a collection of thirteen films that creatively remix material from online archives including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) film material in the National Archives of Australia, crime scene photographs from the Justice and Police Museum Sydney, and Gibson’s own social-media-stored collection of strange late-night phenomena filmed in his neighbourhood over the past decade. Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 2)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Football match between Carlton and Richmond at Punt Road oval. Huge crowd. Good shots of football being played and the crowd reacting to the game.

Section 2. Two women at an observation point above the city.

Section 3. Shot of State Library with tram going past, shot of two statues in the city.

Section 4. Shots taken from behind St Paul’s cathederal looking down towards the Yarra, MCG and Flinders St train tracks.

Section 5. Shots of various statues and fountains around Melbourne.

Section 6. Shot from car driving along St Kilda Road, away from the city.

Section 7. Shots of city in the afternoon. Busy scene with Cars, buses, trams and people.

Section 8. Shot looking towards city from bank of Yarra. A man sits on a park bench in the foreground, surrounded by Seagulls.
